description: From Middle English fynyte, finit, from Latin fīnītus, perfect passive participle of fīniō (“I finish; I terminate”), from fīnis (“boundary”). Displaced native Old English ġeendodlīċ.

adjectives.description: finite (comparative more finite, superlative most finite)

entries.meaning: Having an end or limit; (of a quantity) constrained by bounds; (of a set) whose number of elements is a natural number.
(grammar, as opposed to infinite or nonfinite) Limited by (i.e. inflected for) person or number. [from 19th c.]
examples: The "goes" in "he goes" is a finite form of a verb, the third-person singular.
